author: tenij000

title: Auto shutdown (off) when print is finished

description.text:
With this modification the printer turns off 10 minutes later after the
print ist finished.
It is a master off, no stand-by current.

Just print 0.3layer @60mm/s.
Put the printbed connector under your printbed.
Put the switch in place that it will be pushed from the printbed
connector when the printbed ist fully down.
After 10 minutes printing has ended, main power (230V) will
disconnected. Endswitch is only on 24V. You need an additional
"start" button.
How it works? Press shortly the start button to close primary power (230V)
printbed = up -> switch = closed (@24V)
load the condensator to 24V, @0.8V transistor close -> relay pull
-> relay close primary power (230V).
End of print printbed (Z) goes down.
Switch open -> condensator starts discharging
After 10minutes condensator bellow 0.8V -< transistor open
-> relay open -> mainpower open -> off

A waterproof printable board for "Mensch ärgere Dich nicht".
The cavities are designed to fit coins: 1 Euro-cent on the field, 2 cents in the edges. Although the cent coins are sputtered with copper the core is an iron based alloy which gives them ferromagnetic properties. Therefore small magnets can be fitted into the figures, making them stick to the field.
The coins make it quite heavy though, it won't float by it self, I use it in my swiming pool placed on a piece of styrofoam. Have fun!

Track light that sits on a TechLighting low voltage track.  You can install an MR16 socket into it, and a couple of bolts (an M6 and something smaller on the bottom) to clamp it to the track and provide your electical connection.  The light is aimable via a 30mm ball and socket, and you could add extensions if you wanted a gooseneck.  
WARNING:  DO NOT INSTALL A HALOGEN OR INCANDESCENT IN A PLASTIC LIGHT FIXTURE; THEY WILL BE TOO HOT AND IT WILL MELT.  MONITOR YOUR LAMPS TEMPERATURE AND ENSURE YOU'RE NOT CREATING A FIRE OR MELTING HAZARD.  EVEN SOME LEDs PRODUCE A LOT OF HEAT.  EXPERIMENTAL.  USE AT YOUR OWN RISK.

This is my mounting system for my minimalistic spool ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8331 ), but it should work with most other spools with a bearing center, like "Simple spool system for a Mendel (or other 3d printer)" by brokentoaster ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3962 ) and its derivatives, and "Another spool" by CCphoto ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8208 ). It mounts to the back of a Cupcake and has a filament guide to lift the filament up and feed it down into the extruder. In the pictures, it's holding about a pound of plastic. The spool can hold a full 5lb roll, but I wouldn't want to put more than 2 or 3 pounds on this mounting, because of the torque on the Makerbot's body panels. The STLs are for M6 rods, but the scad file is parametric, so you can use whatever size you want.

Remember the left hand rule (a.k.a. FBI rule) to work out the direction of the Lorentz force as a result of a current flowing through a magnetic field? Or maybe you're in high school struggling with it at the moment? You'll find that sometimes Physics exams will have you strain your left wrist to solve questions on the Lorentz force.  
Tutoring people in high school I saw that this can be a real pain and a source of frustration. That's when I came up with the FBI tool. You slide the tool onto a pencil, point the pencil in the direction of the current, turn it to have the B arrow point in the direction of the magnetic field and F will point in the direction of the force. Easy, simple, clean, without breaking a sweat or a wrist.

Just print it, PLA works fine, 0.15 mm layer height. I printed without brim or support to prevent the letters from filling up. If necessary, some scaling may be applied to make it fit on a different pencil or a pen. I've included the SCAD file, so you can tweak and adapt whereever necessary.

description.text:
I recently made a tap handle for use with small taps to make threaded holes for screws ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:844370 ). This is the same tap but with a knob at the top that spins so you can apply pressure with one hand and spin it with the other. The whole thing prints as one object. Here is a video of it spinning (I'd use youtube if I could without giving up my phone number, but I can't): https://vid.me/bnQW The way it works is that the knob is supported by a little 1mm diameter post which you can see in the cutaway views. When the print is done, you just twist the knob to snap that post and it will then spin freely. You'll want to print pointy side down (I used a brim). You'll have to rotate this file 180 degrees in your slicer most likely. If you print it with the knob at the bottom, the entire weight of the handle will be supported only by a 1mm column of plastic. Notes:
1-The source file is in FreeCAD native file format.
2-The square tap hole is 3.5mm which accounts for the side-ooze on my printer -- it fits my 2.8mm taps, but you may need to edit that for yours.
3-Also, the knob is sort of wobbly while printing. Mine came out fine despite that but you may want to decrease its mass by chopping the knob down.
4-Lastly, it occurred to me in the last print that it might print faster if the square hole for the tap was shorter and you just let the printer do a natural fill job. A 1cm depth would be more than ample. You could just add a cylinder to fill most of the extraneous square hole.

description.text:
a simple tetragonal Pyramid (C4, C4V)
a=b, c=2a
FreeCad

Update 5/28/2015 -- I uploaded new .stl files for Male bottom and Female bottom.  The originals were too "square"; the new versions are more rounded.  They're not exactly the same as my reference (wooden Pill), but much closer to the same profile.

Kenama Pill toy (you will need to provide the string; e.g., http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00P4OILO4). It is designed in multiple parts for two reasons:

  • For strength, the spike needs to be printed horizontally (layers along the length of the spike), as I expected, and proved to be true with my kendama design(s) (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:806955 and subsequent second version, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:833183).

  • Both ends of the pill are nearly (but not) flat, rendering support material unusable; each end really needs to print facing upwards. So, each pill piece (male/female) is printed in two halves, and fastened together with a push-and-twist design (see exploded view; again, the ring and clips are separate so the clips can be oriented for strength; to prevent the ring from splitting on a layer).

All parts should be printed as-is. No support is required for any parts. The Retainer Ring includes it's own "brim" to help anchor it to the print plate... from the inside. You don't need the Exploded .stl file; it is here only for instructional purposes; to show how the pill pieces are assembled. Print one each of Female top/bottom, Male top/bottom, and Spike tip.
Print two Spike halves, and Retainer rings.
Print six Retainer clips. The top/bottom halves of the Male and Female pill pieces are each joined using 1 retaining ring and 3 retainer clips (see the exploded view). Place the three clips into the ring, and insert into bottom half of the Female pill piece, and twist them to lock them into the bottom half. Next, push the top half down onto the clips & ring, and twist to lock the top half to the bottom half. Repeat for the Mail pill piece. Next, insert both spike halves into the male piece so that the "nipple" sticks out the bottom, and the base of the spike "flare" seats flush with the top piece. You will most likely need to sand the shaft a bit in order to push it all the way down. You want it to be nice and snug; it should then not require any glue. Finally attach the spike tip by pressing it on, and twisting it 90 degrees to lock it on and the spike halves together. The pill is now assembled, and only requires the two parts to be tied together with a knendama string (ideally, with a bead too). The string holes are designed to be drilled out. The string hole in the pill piece (female) intentionally does not go all the way through the part so that when printing, it bridges (what will be) the bottom of the spike hole. The string hole through the nipple is best drilled after being assembled to ensure a single, straight, hole through both halves. The hole in the pill can be drilled before or after assembly.

remixed_from.author: bottleworks
remixed_from.title: Aluminum HBP Arms For The Replicator!

description.text:
For more Info, See: http://www.bctechnologicalsolutions.com/replicator2arms
Have you been having issues with your MakerBot Replicator 2 or 2X Z Stage arms warp or excessively vibrate? The Replicator series is a Revolutionary set of 3D printers pushing the limits of small scale 3D printing. As people reach new advances in desktop 3D printing, stability and consistency are critical. The OEM Z Stage arms are made of ABS plastic. Unfortunately, when the plastic arms are exposed to the heat generated by the HBP (Replicator 1 & 2X), they warp, sag, and otherwise move. This warping and sagging make it Incredibly difficult to have a consistently level HBP. As a result, constant tweaks and adjustments are required. Another issue is the low mass and flexibility of the plastic arms. During high speed printing, the OEM arms, lightly vibrate. These vibrations contribute to further distort the object being printed. This is less apparent in the Replicator 2, but artifacts continue to appear during high speed printing.
Virtually eliminate these issues by upgrading to custom CNC milled aluminum Z Stage arms. These replacement arms are made out of a single solid piece of 6061 aluminum.
  • The arms are designed to replace the original plastic arms.
  • There are 4 bearing retainers which you can print yourself, or can be purchased with included hardware.
  • 4 new LM10UU linear bearings for the Z axis included
  • No more constant adjustments due to unwanted arm movement.
  • Greatly reduced platform vibration (springboard effect).
  • Each set comes with step-by-step installation instructions in full color.
    • For users with 3D printed bearing retainers, free acrylic retainers are available. The 3D printed retainers can crack in certain conditions. Contact the support email for replacements.

Everything is to be printed with ABS plastic.
Print the bearing plates with 100% fill.
Print the rest with 10-12% infill, 2 extra shells.
The "full" back plate is an optional version that helps remove some "hidden" areas where plastic bits can fall into and get lost.

The provided instructions are clear and full of photos, leaving little doubt about what you need to do.  My installation took about 90 minutes, but I went slow. This kit is well worth the money and I would not hesitate to do it all over again.  It saves you time if you buy the HBP and install everything at the same time. This test piece constists of 4 10x10mm squares at 100mm distance on the outside and one 10mm diameter circle in the dead middle. 
Use this to calibrate your machines X and Y axis as well as ensure you have 200x200mm print bed by scaling it up by x2. You may wish to work your way up slightly changing the position of the center of the piece until you can print it at x2 scale and it maxing out the corners of your print bed.

Ensure Multiply is on with 100x and 100y and 1 column and 1 row set. The difference between the outside edge and the end stops of your nozzle head will be the measurement you need to know how much you can scale this and try again.

description.text:
Do you have a Brinno construction time lapse camera, like the Brinno TLC 200?  Here's some handy parts to mount it to the inside of a window, or other convenient location. The mount can be attached using 3M Command Strips or double sided sticky tape. It also has holes for insertion of 1/2 inch magnets if you want to be able to attach it magnetically to a metal object.  Also screw holes are provided. On top of the mount are 2 holes for 1/4-20 threaded rod for attaching the camera, for facing either direction.   
Also included is a reflection guard which slips over the lens of the camera to block reflections from inside lighting when recording though a window.

You will need a length of 1/4-20  (read quarter-twenty) treaded rod or bolt for attaching your camera. A wing nut is handy too. Use 1/2 strong magnets if you wish to attach magnetically to a metal object. 3M command strips or double sided sticky tape are handing for attaching to the inside of window.

description.text: Injection molded project boxes are great for high quality stuff, but 3D printed boxes give you more choices of size and you can print them on demand with the holes you need pre-cut already. For example, if you have a larger printer you can print out the box needed with the holes pre-cut to make the temperature process controller box seen in the main photo. Build instructions for that can be found here: http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-Automate-ANY-Temperature-Controlled-Process/ (FYI the box shown in the main photo was NOT 3d printed).

Dimensions provided are all exterior to the box with the lid off. All box walls are 3/16" thick. 4 screws will be needed to secure the lid in place but the lid is sized to be a snap fit.
I recommend printing with 2 perimeters at 30% infill minimum. If you don't see the size you need you can always pick the closest size box and scale it a bit, but not too much. I've found the 3/16" wall thickness to be ideal for 3D printed boxes. I've also provided the source file for one box in 'Cubify Design' software format.
Leafs logo keychain
If your printer only has one extruder, you can still make this blue and white by printing the base in blue, and then switching to white for the text.

This is pretty sweet.  I have a 2.5" telescope that's getting old, but still works very well.  Being a newbie star gazer, I have absolutely no knowledge of star names or know where to look for them.  There are a number of apps that are very good at names and locations, so I decided to marry my iPhone to my telescope thinking it might help me out.  
I wasn't prepared for the result.  I thought the app would get me in the neighborhood of where I wanted to be, but I had no idea how accurate the setup would be.  Because the clamp is locked into position, everything is automatically set in place.  The telescope's area of coverage is dead center on the iPhone's screen.  If I type a star's name, the app shows me which direction to point my telescope.  
The app I use is Sky View. There are both free and paid versions in the app store.  Sky View has a virtual reality mode that shows the actual sky along with the graphics.  A target in the middle of the iPhone screen highlights the star when the scope is pointed directly at it.  Not only does this make it easy for me to locate any star, but I gain a little knowledge about it as well.  
The device will hold the iPhone vertically or horizontally.

The print is made in 2 parts so the entire project can be made without supports.  The clamp portion with the hinge is printed as one part.  The iPhone holder is separate.  Glue this part to the clamp.  I use a mixture of scrap plastic and acetone.  This attaches parts together as well as a weld does.   
The plastic hinge worked loose on the prototype after I cranked the wing nut too hard.  I've added a small hole for a wire to be inserted.  Depending on what size wire is available, the hole can be enlarged to fit.  Drill the hole undersize to keep the wire in place.  I drilled a 0.093 dia hole through the center of the hinge I had weakened, and pressed a 0.100 stainless wire into it.   Now, the part should last a long time.  
Post Posting Notes:  
With a bit of post-printing modification, this should fit a 2" to 3" telescope.  
Not everyone has a 3D printer, so I'm including a pop-riveted aluminum version that should be simple to make.  Look at the drawing, use the concept and size it to your telescope and phone.  Don't forget to put padding between the aluminum, pop rivets and your telescope.  
I've been bitten by the astronomy bug... I ordered a 114mm reflector and re-draw a new iPhone holder.  I'm thinking of mating it directly to the spotter scope's permanent mount.  I won't be needing the spotter and I can use the adjustment screws to fine tune the phone's alignment.

title: USB thing holder with center hole for magnet

description.text:
Remix of USB thing holder by ghostling (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19703). I modified the center hole to fit either a 0.5inch or 10mm magnet and cleaned up the .stl some. Adding the magnet both secures the usb devices in the holder, and allows the holder to be mounted to a magnetic surface. I used a 0.5" round x 0.5" long SmCo magnet. There is a step in the hole to fit a 10mm magnet as well, but I don't have a magnet that size to test it. Either size of magnet will likely need to be a rare earth type to support the weight. You may have to glue the magnet in. Solid models are included in the .zip file (.STEP .IGS .x_t .SLDPRT) And no the magnet wont hurt the data on the flash drives.
http://www.techhive.com/article/116572/article.html
I printed with Cura, .25mm layers, 50% infill,  1mm shell, and 1mm top and bottom.

description.text:
Here are parts for lower stomach designed for humanoid robot InMoov designed by 'hairygael'. All parts are designed in Autodesk 123Design.
Component 'PivWormV2_scaled1point43.stl'is not my part. Is designed by 'hairygael' and just scaled to bigger size.

Update: New MiddleBottom6_Ring4.stl is here. It can hold PotHolder PivPotentioV2.stl from InMoov Shoulder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40040
by 'hairygael' or any another compatible PotHolder.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:535173 Uff I'm hurry up. Ok, I will provide Instructions in english later.
I hope a few pictures on my blog are selfExplanatory. :-)
http://andrejrobotika.blogspot.sk/2015/05/spodna-cast-brucha-pre-robota-inmoov.html
It just need to add two big servos Hitec MG805 BB. They need to be modified to 'continuous rotation'.

ImmersionRC Vortex 10 degree Mobius camera mount. Designed to be used with a velcro strap up to 16mm in width. I got tired of losing MicroSD cards in crashes so I added a little tab on the back to keep the card in place during crashes. A beefier version with more protection and cutouts on the bottom that lets you zip tie it to the vibration plate is available in my store. Options for a 10 and 15 degree versions. http://fpv-flightclub.com/product/vortex-mobius-mount/ I re-uploaded the file with a logo because people were selling my designs. Sorry.

This collection of living jewellery was made during the 2013 FabJam at leFabShop Paris. The voted theme, shared with 15 other Fab spaces around the world was Â«Urban FarmingÂ». We all had one afternoon to prototype our ideas and this is what the designers Sanam Viseux and Samuel N. Bernier came out with. Of course, they didn't have to time to grow flowers for real, but the idea is pretty sweet.   
The models were made on SolidWorks, so sorry if the file imports upside down.

description.text: So I made a zip tie mount here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:83689 And I decided to remake it from scratch. This one is open where the zip ties cross and like the other one can be held down by 2 zip ties in either orientation. I think this one is better.

comments.text: I mounted mine to a helmet and put it through a pretty good workout doing some water rescue training. No issues. Thanks for posting this!
comments.author: mr_wes

comments.text: I printed this at a slight angle so there wouldn't be that straight layer that makes a weak point on the fingers' start.
comments.author: Joscar

comments.text: Rotate the nut hole by 30deg to remove that tiny overhang and that will make that bit print better.
comments.author: josephdouce

comments.text: ^ this
comments.author: josephdouce

comments.text: I made one in ABS, and while squeezing the top three attachment guides to test for strength they snapped off.  Worried if the camera took a hit they could do the same.  I'm going to try a solid infill and see if it improves.  Will post the results.  Thanks for this file!
comments.author: ghenry

comments.text: With ABS layer adhesion is the problem. To get the strongest fingers 1 perimeter and 100% infill, do not do more than 1 perimeter or the infill will be sparse.
comments.author: ghenry

comments.text: I printed one and I have attached to my helmet and it works great, I have not been able to test much but at least I have endured and seems to stand up well, although the characteristics of my helmet I had to use four elastic straps, and that has made the camera move

A bread knife with an exchangeable, parametric blade.
As it seems, it also cuts fingers. Now I'm bleeding :-/

Just use the included STL files. You'll need:
  • 1 x grip
  • 1 x blade fixture (three sizes provided)
  • 1 x blade (four provided)
  • 1 x (3x16)mm screw
  • 1 x 3mm nut
    • The blade fixture comes in three sizes.
    Start with size "M" ("BreadKnife_BladeFixM_V10.stl"), it will fit in most (tm) cases.
    The "S" variant is a little smaller, for fat printing machines and the "X" type a little larger, for precision freaks. The blade should be printed with a layer height of 0.1mm or less, preferably on a glass surface. The tang might require some deburring on the bottom side. Notice that the blade fixure is not symmetric!
    The bottom is slightly inclined to match the shape of the blade.

If you own Rhino 3D, you can customize your own blade with the included Grasshopper script.
Please see "BreadKnife3.png" for an example on how to place the tip and fixture (tang) curves.
The knife geometry will be extended at x=0. The hole in the grip (and the tang) is at x=-15mm, measured from the front. As of now, the shape of the tang directly depends on the geometry of the blade, hence changing any of the parameters will require an optical comparison with a "baked" original or one of the provided STLs. Default, working parameters:
  • blade width 25mm
  • thickness blade back: 3mm
  • thickness blade front: 1mm
  • tang 15mm, centered
    • Remember to align the blade with the xy plane.
    Simply rotate it in the right view and lay it flat. Good luck.
    Oh - and watch your fingers :-/

title: 3-point levelling for Ultimaker with magnetic ball bearings V2

description.text: Version 2 of 3-point levelling for Ultimaker with magnetic ball bearings.

Required parts: 3x 7mm magnetic balls
3x M4 35mm socket heat bolts
6x M4 washers
3x M4 Nylon nuts
3x M4 regular nuts
2x M3 10mm bolts
4x M3 35mm bolts Tempered glass print bed replacement or use existing acrylic bed. Print all three parts. Size all holes with needle file so that respective bolts pass unhindered, especially the M4 holes.
Remove print bed, then remove all 4 levelling bolts. Don't loose the levelling springs!
Bolt the extension arms in place directly to the sides of the z-platform arms.
Drill a 4.5mm on the laser cut spacer panel mid way between the screw blocks at the back. To properly drill the 3mm fixing holes, bolt the printed nut bed on the top side of the spacer panel, slightly tighten it and line up the fixing holes, then drill the 3mm holes.
Bolt the nut bed at the bottom side of the spacer panel. Levelling bolts (M4) are fixed by first screwing in a regular nut all the way to the socket head, then passing them upwards through their respective holes (extension arms and nut bed). The nuts should easily sink in the hex receptacles to prevent them from rotating.
Place a spring on each, then a washer, then a Nylon bolt. Use a socket wrench to tighten the Nylon nuts just one turn.
Place the magnetic balls on the Nylon nuts.
Place a washer on each of the magnetic balls.
Place the print bed on the three levelling points, see that the bed sits on all three washers.
Remove the print bed, place few drops of cyanoacrylate (super) glue on the washers, then place the print bed carefully on these washers. Make sure that your Z-stop is readjusted properly so that your print nozzle doesn't crash on the print bed. Level the print bed using whatever means you prefer. I used a dial gauge.
First tighten the slack on the spring at the back. Move the nozzle (dial gauge) on top of it. Move the print platform up using the worm gear coupler and stop when the dial gauge touches the print bed and moves 0.05mm or so. Reset the dial gauge to zero. Move the nozzle to the other level points and adjust the levelling bolts to read zero on the dial gauge. Move to the back and check that it still reads zero, then the middle. Next, make fine adjustments to the Z-stop switch to stop the nozzle at the prescribed hight above the print bed. Happy level printing. Enjoy! If you like this design, feel free to donate and ask for improvements:
https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=AW57FTXN35YZE

comments.author: murat

comments.text: I've been using the same magnets for 9 months now without any noticeable degradation. However, the main worry is the stability of the arms when printing ABS where the bed temperature is 110C. It was a very hot day, the garage was easily 45C and whilst printing ABS, the arms that I had originally printed in PLA started creeping. So I quickly re-levelled the table and printed the arms in ABS. For good measure, I taped some cork insulation on top of the arms. So, if you are going print ABS, first print new arms in ABS before the PLA ones become useless.

Someone pointed that I should cut my threaded rod below the stock acrylic parts hole but I don't want to cut it instead I took the trouble to model a bracket that doesn't hold the threaded rod. This is often for those who are having wobble issues where the threaded rod already bent (like mine here https://youtu.be/kOVKfpDfA9U) and needs to be replaced. It does fixed my problem but only for lower layers by around 3cm of print layers only before the wobble starts to occur again. At least it somehow fixed the problem temporarily

There are 2 files included, if you have a bad wobble issues, print with the 1mm wobble file first because it does fit on my first print. However the smooth rood bracket for the 1mm wobble thing are not aligned with the original bracket. Use it for temporary fix to your wobble problem then print the other one.  
Printed with about 20% infill, 4 bottom/top and 3 layer of walls

comments.text: My z axis wasn't noticably bent... but like all printers with threaded rods instead of lead screws there was some encoding of the thread pattern on the parts... by not trying to bind the rods, and freeing them like your doing here you get WAAAAYYYY better prints, and NOT just for people with bend rods. It will help anyone with threaded rods. Let your smooth rods do their jobs and unbind them from the threaded rods! :P

title: Close Tolerance Open Access Belt Fender

description.text:
I needed a bit more room on my print bed and the only thing preventing that was the fender washers on the Y bearings. The Y carriage was bumping into them so I decided to replace them with flat sided ones. This is my first "real" part here on thingiverse. So I hope someone actually uses it and likes it. Thanks for any constructive feedback. Ver 1 was too big! (60mm diameter)
Ver 2 slot seems a bit small.
Ver 3 Should just end on the flat side right next to the 608 bearing, Added a couple of clips that might help.
Ver 4 Removed one of the clips, lowered the height to just under 2mm
Download, print. One on each side should work fine. But if you're worried about the belt catching, or the fender falling off; use two on the same side, one inverted, for complete enclosure.

description.text:
This allows a container to be held under a 0.5" diameter drain line. Works great for draining tail rotor gearboxes. *Note, if you would like this tool for a different outside diameter drain tube, please let me know in the comment section. Created with https://www.onshape.com/ Don't have a printer?
http://www.shapeways.com/shops/ThinkTank
or
Download Files and go to https://www.3dhubs.com/

Print upside down.  You may have to use supports for the indent in the side.  Once printed, stick a long cotter key through hole, cut to size and bend cotter key flush with indent.  The cotter key eye hole, allows a hook to be placed into it.  
Stick a 0.5" outside diameter drain tube through the center hole.  *Note, there are grooves/ridges in the center hole that must be placed in the correct direction to help prevent tool from sliding off the hose.
Cub Scout Arrow of Light Logo

It is a bracket that holds a dimmer and a .28" volt meter onto the Rostock max V2's melamine lid. The purpose of this is to control a 15 LED angel light ring around the hot end and have a volt meter just because. I included a version of the bracket without the volt meter if you don't want to run one. See it work here: https://youtu.be/C1I-3bAwU-U

ABS or PLA will work for this part. It fits on the edge snug as is, but there are clearance holes for two 6-32 bolts if you want it to be securely mounted to the platform. Run wires from the power supply to the dimmer and the volt meter. On the dimmer output wires, run them through an aluminum extrusion to the top and run them down with the hotend wires to the lights on the hotend platform. If you are not using an LED circuit with resistors, make sure you are safe and add some between the dimmer and LED's. This allows you to control the LED's brightness and lets you have them off if you aren't in the room with the printer. I used a Supernight Aluminum dimmer I got off amazon here: http://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00JQ437YM/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 Voltmeter I used, you can use a 2 wire if you want: http://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00IWLU8YC/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

I decided to 3D print a bracket that will hold my phone at the bottom of  the wheel. It works very well, although I would prefer it being higher. Maybe I will try to make a different version that mounts at the top next.  
I am using HUD Dash from the play store as the software to power the display. It works with Project Cars, Assetto Corsa, iRacing and several other sims. Those are the three I use it with.

• Print all three STL files (I used PLA).
  • Glue (I used hot glue) the three parts together (see pictures).
  • Put the bracket on your wheel, its a bit tricky, but it will go.
  • Put your Galaxy Nexus in the bracket.
  • Install a HUD program and enjoy.

title: Filament Spool Bracket and Hub Set

description.text:
Was looking for a more elegant solution to holding the spool than what comes with the TAZ Printer.  
The bracket will clamp right onto the printer frame, just use 6 M4x40mm Screws and one 5/16x6 inch screw with square base and rounded head.  
The Spool hubs fit most of the popular spool sizes for filament.

Print the bracket and hubs. Use the 5/16 screw on the bracket and mount the bracket to the printer. Use the spool hubs on your spools to mount them to the screw on the bracket. The Screw that fits the spools may need to be changed for an M8 if metric or 5/16. If a 5/16 screw is used you may need to drill the hubs to fit the screw. Use one nut, 1 flat washer and one compression washer to mount the screw to the bracket. Use 2 flat washers one on the outer sides of the hubs and an additional nut to hold the spool in place.
In case you wanted to there are some spacers in the design.

title: Improved Bed Mount for RepRapPro Mendel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is an improved bed mount for the version of the RepRapPro Mendel which uses M3 screws to attach the bed. It eliminates the fiddly three nut system and replaces them with a spacer and a single nyloc nut. This makes bed leveling and adjustment much easier.

This is a drop-in replacement for the current M3-based bed mounts. Insert a M3 nyloc nut into the nut trap on the mount. A small amount of filing may be required but it needs to be a tight fit. Attach the new mount then attach the bed as follows (top to bottom):
  • M3 caphead screw
  • M3 washer
  • Bed
  • Spring
  • Printed spacer
  • Bed mount
    • The printed spacer is optional depending on your springs. It is the same height as the two M3 nuts that were previously used so when used will put the springs under the same compression as before.

description.text: By Eunny

This is a housing for the clock kit I bought from BangGood. I bought this:
http://www.banggood.com/DIY-DS1302-Rotation-LED-Electronic-Clock-Kit-51-SCM-Learning-Board-p-956298.html
but they have since made a slightly different version. They now sell a box to go with it but what the hey - why not make it? It turned out really nice. The only thing I didn't like is that it only came as a 24-hour clock.

It came with plastic metric spacers but since I didn't have metric mating hardware, I used some #4 spacers, 5/8" long. The housing length is designed around this. I also mounted the switches on the front of the board accidentally but since it looked just as good, I left them there and made buttons to accommodate them. I bought 2.5mm acrylic sheet from McMaster-Carr.  
Files are in Inventor format. Let me know if you'd like step files.

description.text: Hold Pencils, Pens, Rubbers, Glue.

Enemy mini for the Shadows of Brimstone: City of the Ancients board game.  40mm base.  
(See instructions for assembly)

Print only the targa-pylon.stl for gameplay. Base is not need to stand upright. If you want to go the extra mile, you can purchase a 3mm LED light, a slide switch, and wire the two together with a CR2016 (or similar) button cell battery. The targa-pylon-base.stl file has a cutout sized for a 6VDC .3A DPDT slide switch from Radioshack (part 2750007.) The small circular inset on the underside is for a 1/4"x1/16" rare earth magnet -- glue one in place and the battery can be held inside without clips. Snap on the targa-pylon-base-cap.stl to hide the battery and your poor soldering job. Radioshack link for switch: http://comingsoon.radioshack.com/6vdc-0-3a-dpdt-slide-switch/2750007.html#.VWLKcU_BzRY Amazon link for magnets: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0012AUU84/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

1/2 inch piping fits in the main hole, 1/4in for the smaller ones.  
This is NOT a complete model. Simply a fix for the corrupted files in Garin's thing.  
Parts included here are not intended as a complete model and are for kit-bashing purposes only. Copyright infringement is not intended. All parts are created freehand in 3d modeling software, no copyrighted product had been scanned or directly copied in any way.

description.text:
I have a few paint tools, such as telescoping poles, that all use the same standard threads.  Besides painting, I've seen the same or similar standards used for brooms, lightbulb grips, pool tools, and gutter cleaning poles.  
Apparently there are two standards common in the USA, both based on a 3/4" dowel (0.75 inch or 19mm).  One standard (shown here) has a pitch of 5 threads per inch; the other has 4 threads per inch.  However, there is a LOT of variation due to the manufacturing of wood, plastic, milled aluminum, and cast aluminum tools on the market.  
These objects are just the blanks, ready for combining into any other project.  I've put in generous clearances, and a tapering thread at the shank end to help keep tools snugly fit regardless of thread sizing.  I will post a 4-thread version too.  Do any other global standards exist for these pole fittings?

remixed_from.title: screw for a car wash mop

description.text: BonsaiBrain was onto something when he designed the car wash mop! That screw is used in a lot of other things as well.  Mops, floor sponges, paint rollers, squeegees, drywall sanders, brooms, etc.  Seems to be universal in janitorial supplies.  These files are basic Male/Female parts that could be adapted to whatever configuration you need. I've also included two examples that I have used.  One is a Female version with a flange to screw onto whatever you need to, the other is an adapter I designed to attach a feather duster to an extendable painter's pole so that I could dust a ceiling fan.

title: PrintrBot Metal Plus C270 Webcam Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A simple mount for a Logitech C270 webcam that mounts directly onto the PrintrBot Metal Plus case. You can use the existing machine screws (there is enough thread or you can buy slightly longer ones up to you but I have been using the existing ones and it works just fine.   
For assembly I used some M4 machine screws and some wing nuts and the Camera mount post needs to be glued together with a little dot of super glue.Remove the camera's OEM stand and use the same pin to secure it to the camera port.

title: Little Fadecandy Ring
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a set of snap-together parts for learning to use the Fadecandy LED controller platform.
  • Snap a Fadecandy into the base
  • Snap in an Adafruit 12-LED NeoPixel ring
  • Press three wires into the channels
  • Solder the wires in place and trim
  • Optionally print and attach a diffuser, mix and match
  • Program your LEDs with Processing, Javascript, Python, etc
    • This design is still a work in progress; I'll try to retain compatibility with the interface between the base and diffusers, but at this point there aren't any guarantees. The base works with PLA, but ABS or PET will be a little nicer. For diffusers, try materials with various opacities. (Dyed white PET vs natural translucent white PLA, for example)

author: scanlime

description.text: I couldn't find any satisfying pencil clips, so I made a couple.

I used support obviously. I printed them with the shank flat to get the most strength from the filament as well as the best finish for the show side.
The elephant prints easily and diamond uses a flat backed crystal glued in place for decoration. On the paint can clip, I added a small post as I was not able to get a good print without it. It breaks off easily and came off with the rest of the support structure for me.
I had to use a brim, 15 lines and 2 layers to help everything stay together while printing. I haven't tried printing on end, but it would work well, sacrificing a little strength and alignment of layers for printing without support.
Enjoy!
Simonarri on Instagram

remixed_from.author: Tech2C
remixed_from.title: Compact Bowden Extruder, 1.75mm Filament for MK7 Drive Gear

title: Compact Bowden Extruder MK7 Drive Gear with 1/8 size Push In Fitting

description.text:
I have modified the MK7 drive gear version of the compact Bowden extruder found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:767951
to accommodate a 1/8 size push in fitting from here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:835542 I have also added a mirrored version for mounting on the left side of your printer. I have these extruders mounted on a 5/16" threaded rod which also supports the z axis on my prusa I3. The mirrored version allows me to mount it onto the left side bar while still having the drive gear facing towards me.
You will want to heat up the hole for the push in fitting before screwing in the fitting or the part may crack. I heated it up for a quick second and was easily able to screw it in by hand.

comments.text: I noticed that this is for the smaller sized MK7 drive gear. Just FYI.. I have it together wit the larger gear and the plastic material is bowed out by the larger gear, but it looks like it will still work this way for PLA and PETG (have not run it on the printer yet though).

These are replacement lenses for the awesome Adafruit NeoPixel Goggles (https://www.adafruit.com/products/2221). The lenses include a dualstrusion "camera iris" style design. I printed these in black ABS designs over clear PLA lenses. They show the LED animations really well. Just unscrew the goggles cap, pull out the various lenses, and replace with these. One design is flipped, so you don't have to do it in software.

title: MakerBot Flower
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: For my first MakerBot project I made a white flower.

I used Inventor for this project.  To create the design I made a circle with a diameter of 0.25 in. in the center of the plane.  Then I created an ellipse touching the top of the circle.  I used the circular pattern tool to create the rest of the petals.  Next, I extruded the flower and saved the file as a .ipt and .stl.  I saved the STL file to my flash drive and plugged it into the computer for the Thing-O-Matic.  While the software generated the G Code, I changed the color of the plastic to white and heated up the platform and extruder.  The print took about 25 minutes.

description.text:
A straight-forward calibration piece for setting up extrusion and your X and Y axis travel.
This was inspired by the Euro-coin Calibration by momorientes.

I have written an in-depth tutorial on how to perform a correct calibration using this thing. You can find it Here:
http://blog.mcmelectronics.com/post/3D-printer-calibration For best effect, print with 100% fill, as this will highlight extrusion problems.
